entities: United Nations Mission in Ethiopia and Eritrea
summary:
The Security Council,
Recalling previous resolutions and statements on the Ethiopia-Eritrea conflict, reaffirms commitment to the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of both countries. 
Reaffirming the need for both parties to fulfil obligations under international humanitarian, human rights and refugee law, and recalling the Convention on the Safety of United Nations and Associated Personnel. 
The Council reaffirms support for the Agreement of Cessation of Hostilities and the Comprehensive Peace Agreement, and welcomes progress made in their implementation. 
The Council extends the mandate of UNMEE at current troop and military observer levels until 15 September 2001. 
The parties are called upon to: 
- Work towards full and prompt implementation of their Agreements; 
- Ensure freedom of movement and access for UNMEE; 
- Establish a direct air corridor between Addis Ababa and Asmara; 
- Conclude Status of Forces Agreements; 
- Facilitate mine action. 
The termination of the UN peacekeeping mission is linked to the completion of the Ethiopia-Eritrea border delimitation and demarcation process. 
The parties are urged to fund the Boundary Commission and the Council encourages UNMEE to provide support. 
The Council calls on States and international organizations to provide support to the peace process, including contributions to the voluntary Trust Fund. 
The Council decides to remain seized of the matter.
